page.title: 19A MAN FROM GALGORM
page.content: I sat on the pensioners' seat, placed there by the Borough Council, beside an elderly gentleman and his poodle, Mitzi. As we talked I discovered that in his eighty years he had witnessed many changes. Where we sat had once been part of a garden, the bakery opposite now two storeys with a slate roof had been a one storey thatched inn. "You could buy three quarts of porter for a shilling" he said. I translated this to present_day terms_ six pints for five pence. "Do you sit here everyday?", I asked. He explained that during the day older people used the bench but in the evening the youth of the village congregate there. I looked at the crisp packets, broken bottles and empty tins strewn about and the names scored deep in the wood of the bench. "This bench is one week old today",he said.
